course.subject: LANG
course.name: Advanced Chinese Communication
course.description: This course seeks to advance the Putonghua speaking and Chinese writing abilities of local Hong Kong students who have attained a reasonably high standard in Chinese language on leaving secondary schools. The course materials and learning tasks help students to engage in rigorous intellectual analysis of academic and socio-economic issues and formulate coherent arguments for Putonghua speaking and Chinese writing in demanding situations such as participation in public fora and writing critical essays for publication in the media.
course.prerequisites: Level 4 or above in HKDSE Chinese
course.exclusions: CORE 1416, CORE 1423, LANG 1120 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1121 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1122 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1123 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1124 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1125 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1126 (prior to 2022-23), LANG 1127 (prior to 2022-23)

reviews.author: #001/BULBASAUR
reviews.title: I have crippling depression. (Instructor: YU, Wai Ying)
reviews.comment_content:
As much as I want to write this review in Chinese, I unfortunately lack the knowledge to do it. Supposedly I should have learnt how to do so from this Chinese Language course. Instead, I witnessed the absolute uselessness and mental torture embodied by LANG1117C.

While the contents of most courses at HKUST are almost detached from reality, none are as completely irrelevant and utterly useless as those of LANG1117C. Take LANG4030 (basically English Language for SENG FYP) as an example, even though its stupid course schedule renders its syllabus redundant (e.g. you are taught how to write the FYP proposal ONLY AFTER you have submitted the real proposal to your supervisor), it was at least designed the with philosophy of â€œhelping SENG students graduateâ€ in mind. LANG1117C, on the other hand, is merely a giant middle-finger thrown9 at your face. Your first set of assessments is â€œpromoting culture through recommending selected Chinese Literaturesâ€ which has absolutely zero relationship with any of the majors at HKUST. Your second set of assessments is â€œtaking a stance on some academic topicsâ€ which, again, are not remotely related to anything in our courses of study due to how generic and restrictive the predefined topics are. I hereby can confidently tell you that LANG1117C serves no teaching purposes but rather, exists solely to waste your time, effort, and GPA.

Indeed, one could argue that LANG1117C attempts to nourish within us our senses in humanities and Chinese Culture. After all, this is what holistic education is about, and what common core courses aim to achieve. This argument, however, fails to take into account that this course is mandatory. For HUMA common core courses, I could choose which part of â€œhumanitiesâ€ or â€œChinese Cultureâ€ I would love to immerse myself in - be it history, calligraphy, ethics, etc. LANG1117C, on the contrary, simply forces its irrelevant, useless, uninteresting curriculum down your throat while suppressing freedom of interpretation with its harsh grading. In this course, you are highly discouraged from having interesting interpretation on the selected literatures or your findings because they would result in â€œdeviation from the â€˜true implicationsâ€™ of the course materialsâ€ and earning you a big fat 3/7 score for your assignments. This wholy-demonstrates the fact that LANG1117C even fails at fulfilling the role of a common core course with the simple objective of exposing students to the Chinese Language and hopefully arousing their interests.

In my honest opinion, you would be better off learning Chinese from memes like xue hua piao piao bei feng xiao xiao or ching chang hon chi. This is just how worthless LANG1117C is.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The course instructor was YU, Wai Ying. Stated here because I couldn't choose het on USTSpace's UI.

If you couldn't care less about your grades, then Miss Yu is a good choice for you. Her uplifting tone and humorous personality makes each class very engaging. This would help make LANG1117C look slightly less miserable, I guess.

If you are aiming for anything that is above C-, avoid Miss Yu at all cost. Her requirements are drastically different from other tutorsâ€™, rendering it nigh-impossible to grasp whatever unrealistic qualities she expects from your work. Again, this is evident in the fact that I only got B in this course despite my modest Chinese Language abilities.
reviews.comment_grading: I attained Level 5** in Chinese Language in the HKDSE Examination and only got B in this course. Quite self-explanatory.
reviews.comment_workload:
I have seen courses with higher workload but LANG1117C is nonetheless disproportionately more demanding than similar courses:
1. 4-min individual Chinese literature recommendation presentation (no scripts allowed, so you will have to rehearse a lot in advance)
2. 1500-word individual Chinese literature recommendation essay (you will need to dissect a selected Chinese article in advance and pray to God that your tutor doesnâ€™t find your interpretation â€œirrelevantâ€)
3. 20-min group academic presentation + 5-min Q&A (in groups of 4; again, no scripts allowed)
4. 3000-word individual academic essay (again, you will require a lot of researches and findings, and once again pray to God that your tutor doesnâ€™t nitpick your arguments)

For comparison, a 3-credit common core course like HUMA2588 only has 2 open-book exams (with lenient time limits), a 15-min group presentation (scripts allowed, no Q&A, and is only based on course materials), and a 2000-word essay. You can really see that LANG1117C indeed bends on tormenting your body and soul.

reviews.author: æ¸…é¦™æª¸æª¬
reviews.title: Shittest Course I've Ever Taken - Also Worst Instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Totally meaningless. I dont want to waste the time on the course materials.

Assessments.
2 presentations and 2 written reports.
Just complete them with reasonable quality. You will get a random score anyway. More-than-average efforts are meaningless. They wont improve your grade by any.

minimum 80% attendance, else you are in great trouble. dont dare to try that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructor: Stanley Ho

His teaching is completely trash. only give useless responses to students that are meaningless to the improvement to your work. His lessons are a waste of time. If you like to doing nothing in class and just skip the lessons while having full attendance (just open zoom or just hear him bull shit) - this may be a good instructor for you.
reviews.comment_grading:
dont expect a good grade.

grades are not bad "on average". as they are almost given on random.

You work hard - you get a random grade
You work less - you get a random grade

i dont see the meaning of this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
quite high

4 assessments
second presentation is groupwork

hope you dont get freeriders

final comment - if you can avoid taking this course,  DO IT

reviews.title: æœ‰å•²é›£æ‰æ‘¸
